subject: Re: [junit] debuggers
msgSnippet: ... - do you really need the method coloListAsString() ?  If this method is not in your public API, you re writing an additional methods just in the case of a
messageBody:
> What about this, which is currently supported by JUnit:
>
> assertTrue(
> "Rainbow " + rainbow.colorListAsString() + " unexpectedly does not
> contain " + Color.orange.toString(),
> rainbow.contains(Color.orange));

- do you really need the method 'coloListAsString()'? If this method is not in
your public API, you're writing an additional methods just in the case of a
*failing* test (it doesn't help your design at all).

- let's finish the tests (and be careful when you're copy/pasting the code!):

assertTrue("Rainbow " + rainbow.colorListAsString() + " unexpectedly does not
contain " + Color.orange.toString(), rainbow.contains(Color.orange));
assertTrue("Rainbow " + rainbow.colorListAsString() + " unexpectedly does not
contain " + Color.blue.toString(), rainbow.contains(Color.blue));
assertTrue("Rainbow " + rainbow.colorListAsString() + " unexpectedly does not
contain " + Color.yellow.toString(), rainbow.contains(Color.yellow));
assertTrue("Rainbow " + rainbow.colorListAsString() + " unexpectedly does not
contain " + Color.red.toString(), rainbow.contains(Color.red));
assertTrue("Rainbow " + rainbow.colorListAsString() + " unexpectedly does not
contain " + Color.green.toString(), rainbow.contains(Color.green));
..

- or you can simply have:

import junitx.framework.ListAssert;

ListAssert.assertContains(rainbow, Color.orange);
ListAssert.assertContains(rainbow, Color.blue);
ListAssert.assertContains(rainbow, Color.yellow);
ListAssert.assertContains(rainbow, Color.red);
ListAssert.assertContains(rainbow, Color.green);

you're the judge.

-Vladimir
